> Neil Swingler wrote:
> > There are other idioms for testing exceptions =
which will actually be supported by using clover.
> > e.g.
> > try
> > {
> =
>   somethingDangerous();
> > }
> > catch(Exception exception)
> > {
> >   =
assertEquals("message", exception.getMessage());
> > }
> > 
> > in this cas=
e clover will warn you if the test passed but the exception was never throw=
n i.e. we don't need the fail any more because we've got clover
> 
> Hm. Ha=
s it hurt the team yet that you're now relying on Clover to run 
> all your=
 tests? I'd be worried about that.

Joe,

I don't do that myself (though we=
 do run clover). I follow the rule of testing until boredom replaces fear. =
I'm not scared enough to run clover on the tests. Although it would artific=
ially improve our code coverage percentage (<20% thanks to legacy code) :-)=


- Neil
